With the advent of the automobile, aeroplanes and the spreading use of electricity, [[Petroleum|oil]] became the dominant fuel during the twentieth century. The growth of oil as the largest fossil fuel was further enabled by steadily dropping prices from 1920 until 1973. After the oil shocks of [[1973 oil crisis|1973]] and [[1979 energy crisis|1979]], during which the price of oil increased from 5 to 45 US dollars per barrel, there was a shift away from oil.Yergin, p. 792 Coal, natural gas, and nuclear became the fuels of choice for electricity generation and conservation measures increased energy efficiency. In the U.S. the average car more than doubled the number of miles per gallon. Japan, which bore the brunt of the oil shocks, made spectacular improvements and now has the highest energy efficiency in the world.{{cite web |url= http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2006/key2006.pdf |format= PDF |publisher= International Energy Agency |title= Key World Energy Statistics |year= 2006 |accessdate= 3 April 2007 }} pp. 48–57 From 1965 to 2008, the use of fossil fuels has continued to grow and their share of the energy supply has increased. From 2003 to 2008, coal was the fastest growing fossil fuel.Yergin, p. ? It is estimated that between 100 and 135 billion tonnes of oil has been consumed between 1850 and the present.[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/05/090507072830.htm How Much Oil Have We Used?], [[Science Daily]], 8 May 2009. Retrieved March 2014. ==== Natural Gas ==== {{Main article|Natural Gas|List of countries by natural gas production|List of countries by natural gas consumption}} In 2009, the world use of natural gas grew 31% compared to 2000. 66% of this growth was outside EU, North America, Latin America, and Russia. Source: IEA/OECD === Renewable energy === {{Main article|Renewable energy|List of renewable energy topics by country|Renewable energy commercialization}} {{multiple image |direction = horizontal |align = right |width1 = 220 |width2 = 180 |image1=Global public support for energy sources (Ipsos 2011).png |image2= |caption1=Strong public support for [[renewables]] worldwide in 2011{{harvnb|Ipsos|2011|p=3}} |caption2=Comparison of global potential of the world's [[energy source]]s }} Renewable energy is generally defined as energy that comes from [[Renewable resource|resources]] that are not significantly depleted by their use, such as [[sunlight]], [[wind]], [[rain]], [[tidal power|tides]], [[wave power|waves]] and [[geothermal energy|geothermal heat]].{{cite web |url= http://thebulletin.org/myth-renewable-energy |title= The myth of renewable energy |work= Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists |date= 2011-11-22 |accessdate= 2013-10-03 }} Renewable energy is gradually replacing conventional fuels in four distinct areas: [[electricity generation]], [[solar hot water|hot water]]/[[space heating]], [[motor fuel]]s, and [[Stand-alone power system|rural (off-grid)]] energy services.REN21 (2010). [http://www.harbortaxgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/REN21_GSR_2010_full_revised-Sept2010.pdf Renewables 2010 Global Status Report] p. 15. Based on [[REN21]]'s 2014 report, renewables contributed 19 percent to our energy consumption and 22 percent to our electricity generation in 2012 and 2013, respectively. This energy consumption is divided as 9% coming from traditional biomass, 4.2% as heat energy (non-biomass), 3.8% hydro electricity and 2% electricity from wind, solar, geothermal, and biomass. Worldwide investments in renewable technologies amounted to more than US$214 billion in 2013, with countries like [[Renewable energy in China|China]] and the [[Renewable energy in the United States|United States]] heavily investing in wind, hydro, solar and biofuels.{{cite web |url= http://www.ren21.net/Portals/0/documents/Resources/GSR/2014/GSR2014_full%20report_low%20res.pdf |title= Renewables 2014: Global Status Report |author= [[REN21]] |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/6SKF06GAX?url=http://www.ren21.net/Portals/0/documents/Resources/GSR/2014/GSR2014_full%20report_low%20res.pdf |archivedate= 4 September 2014 |year= 2014 |pages= 13, 17, 21, 25 |deadurl= yes |df= dmy-all }} Renewable energy resources exist over wide geographical areas, in contrast to other energy sources, which are concentrated in a limited number of countries. Rapid deployment of renewable energy and [[efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] is resulting in significant [[Energy security and renewable technology|energy security]], [[climate change mitigation]], and economic benefits.{{cite web |url= http://www.iea.org/Textbase/npsum/ETP2012SUM.pdf |title= Energy Technology Perspectives 2012 |author= International Energy Agency |year= 2012 |work= }} In international public opinion surveys there is strong support for promoting renewable sources such as solar power and wind power.{{cite web |title= Global Trends in Sustainable Energy Investment 2007: Analysis of Trends and Issues in the Financing of Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency in OECD and Developing Countries |url= http://www.unep.org/pdf/72_Glob_Sust_Energy_Inv_Report_(2007).pdf |website= www.unep.org |publisher= United Nations Environment Programme |accessdate= 13 October 2014 |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/6TIFLZQC2?url=http://www.unep.org/pdf/72_Glob_Sust_Energy_Inv_Report_(2007).pdf |archivedate= 13 October 2014 |page= 3 |format= PDF |year= 2007 |deadurl= no |df= dmy-all }} At the national level, at least 30 nations around the world already have renewable energy contributing more than 20 percent of energy supply. National renewable energy markets are projected to continue to grow strongly in the coming decade and beyond.{{cite web |url= http://new.ren21.net/Portals/0/REN21_GFR_2013_print.pdf |title= Renewables global futures report 2013 |author= REN21 |year= 2013 |work= }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The following table shows increasing [[nameplate capacity]], and has [[capacity factor]]s that range from 11% for solar, to 40% for hydropower.{{cite web|url=https://meteolcd.wordpress.com/2015/09/21/electricity-generation-very-different-capacity-factors/|title=Electricity generation: very different capacity factors!|date=21 September 2015|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: right; " |- ! ! 2000 ! 2010 ! 2013 |- | align="left"| North-America || 1,973 || 2,237 || 2,443 |- | align="left"| EU || 1,204 || 2,093 || 2,428 |- | align="left"| Russia || align=right |245 || 239 || 271 |- | align="left"| China || 2,613 || 3,374 || 3,847 |- | align="left"| Asia (-China) || 4,147 || 4,996 || 5,361 |- | align="left"| Africa || 2,966 || 3,930 || 4,304 |- | align="left"| Latin America || 1 502 || 2,127|| 2,242 |- | align="left"|Other || 567 || 670 || 738 |- | align="left"|Total renewable || 15,237 || 19,711|| 21,685 |- | align="left"|Total energy|| 116,958 || 148,736 || 157,485 |- | align="left"|Share || 13.0%|| 13.3%|| 13.8% |- | align="left"|Total nonrenewable || 101,721 || 129,025 || 135,800 |- |} From 2000 to 2013 the total renewable energy use has increased 6,450 TWh and total energy use 40,500 TWh. ==== Hydro ==== {{Main article|Hydroelectricity|Hydropower}} Hydroelectricity is the term referring to electricity generated by [[hydropower]]; the production of electrical power through the use of the kinetic energy of falling or flowing water. In 2015 hydropower generated 16.6% of the world's total electricity and 70% of all renewable electricity,http://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/GSR_2016_Full_Report_REN21.pdf which continues the rapid rate of increase experienced between 2003 and 2009. Hydropower is produced in 150 countries, with the Asia-Pacific region generating 32 percent of global hydropower in 2010. China is the largest hydroelectricity producer, with {{convert|721|TWh|PJ|abbr=on|order=flip}} of production in 2010, representing around 17% of domestic electricity use. There are now three hydroelectricity plants larger than 10 GW: the [[Three Gorges Dam]] in China, [[Itaipu Dam]] in Brazil, and [[Guri Dam]] in Venezuela.{{cite web |url= http://www.worldwatch.org/node/9527 |title= Use and Capacity of Global Hydropower Increases |publisher= Worldwatch Institute |date= January 2012}} Nine of the [[List of countries by electricity production from renewable sources|worlds top 10 renewable electricity producers]] are primarily hydroelectric, one is wind. ==== Marine energy ==== {{Main article|Ocean energy}} [[Marine energy]], also known as ''ocean energy'' and ''marine and hydrokinetic energy'' (MHK) includes [[tidal power|tidal]] and [[wave power|wave]] power and is a relatively new sector of renewable energy, with most projects still in the pilot phase, but the theoretical potential is equivalent to 4–18 million tonne of oil equivalent (toe). MHK development in U.S. and international waters includes projects using devices such as, wave energy converters in open coastal areas with significant waves, tidal turbines placed in coastal and estuarine areas, in-stream [[turbine]]s in fast-moving [[river]]s, ocean current turbines in areas of strong [[marine current]]s, and [[ocean thermal energy converter]]s in deep tropical waters.{{cite web |title=Tethys |url=http://tethys.pnnl.gov/}} ==== Wind ==== {{Main article|Wind power|Wind power by country}} Wind power is growing at the rate of 17% annually, with a worldwide [[Installed wind power capacity|installed capacity]] of 432,883 megawatts (MW) at the end of 2015,{{cite web |url= http://www.gwec.net/global-figures/graphs/ |title= GWEC Global Statistics |author= Global Wind Energy Council }}Lars Kroldrup. [http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/02/15/gains-in-global-wind-capacity-reported/ Gains in Global Wind Capacity Reported] ''Green Inc.'', 15 February 2010.{{cite web |url= http://www.ren21.net/Portals/97/documents/GSR/GSR2011_Master18.pdf |title= Renewables 2011: Global Status Report |author= [[REN21]] |year= 2011 |page= 15 }} and is widely used in [[Wind power in the European Union|Europe]], [[Wind power in China|Asia]], and the [[Wind power in the United States|United States]].[http://www.gwec.net/uploads/media/07-02_PR_Global_Statistics_2006.pdf Global wind energy markets continue to boom – 2006 another record year] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407175732/http://www.gwec.net/uploads/media/07-02_PR_Global_Statistics_2006.pdf |date=7 April 2011 }} (PDF).{{cite web |url= http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2011/03/wind-power-china-picks-up-paceeu-and-us-fall-but-global-market-grows |title= Wind Power: China Picks Up Pace |first= David |last= Beattie |date= 18 March 2011 |work= Renewable Energy World |publisher= }} Several countries have achieved relatively high levels of wind power penetration, such as 21% of Portugal|Portugal]], 16% in [[Wind power in Spain|Spain]], 14% in [[Wind power in Ireland|Ireland]]{{cite web |url= http://www.eirgrid.com/renewables/ |title= Renewables |publisher= eirgrid.com |accessdate= 22 November 2010 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/61DCEYzn0?url=http://www.eirgrid.com/renewables/ |archivedate= 25 August 2011 |df= dmy-all }} and 9% in [[Wind |page= 11 }} As of 2011, 83 countries around the world are using wind power on a commercial basis. Continuing strong growth, by 2016 wind generated 3% of global power annually.http://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/energy-economics/statistical-review-of-world-energy/renewable-energy/wind-energy.html ==== Solar ==== {{Main article|Solar energy|Solar power|Solar power by country}} Solar energy, radiant [[light]] and [[heat]] from the [[sun]], has been harnessed by humans since [[ancient history|ancient times]] using a range of ever-evolving technologies. Solar energy technologies include [[solar heating]], [[solar photovoltaics]], [[concentrated solar power]] and [[solar architecture]], which can make considerable contributions to solving some of the most urgent problems the world now faces. The [[International Energy Agency]] projected that solar power could provide "a third of the global final energy demand after 2060, while CO2 emissions would be reduced to very low levels."http://www.iea.org/Textbase/npsum/solar2011SUM.pdf Solar technologies are broadly characterized as either [[passive solar]] or [[active solar]] depending on the way they capture, convert and distribute solar energy. Active solar techniques include the use of [[photovoltaic system]]s and [[solar thermal collector]]s to harness the energy. Passive solar techniques include orienting a building to the Sun, selecting materials with favorable [[thermal mass]] or light dispersing properties, and designing spaces that [[Ventilation (architecture)|naturally circulate air]]. From 2012 to 2016 solar capacity tripled and now provides 1.3% of global energy.http://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/energy-economics/statistical-review-of-world-energy/renewable-energy/solar-energy.html ==== Geothermal ==== {{Main article|Geothermal energy|Geothermal power}} [[Geothermal energy]] is used commercially in over 70 countries.{{cite web |publisher= [[MIT]] |title= The Future of Geothermal Energy |url= http://geothermal.inel.gov/publications/future_of_geothermal_energy.pdf |format= PDF |accessdate= 7 February 2007 |archive-url= https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20110310030646/http://geothermal.inel.gov/publications/future_of_geothermal_energy.pdf |archive-date= 10 March 2011 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }} In 2004, {{convert|200|PJ|TWh}} of electricity was generated from geothermal resources, and an additional {{convert|270|PJ|TWh}} of geothermal energy was used directly, mostly for space heating. In 2007, the world had a global capacity for {{val|10|u=GW}} of electricity generation and an additional {{val|28|u=GW}} of [[geothermal heating|direct heating]], including extraction by [[geothermal heat pumps]].{{cite web |url= http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/download/RE_GSR_2006_Update.pdf |format= PDF |publisher= Renewable Energy Policy Network for the 21st century |title= Renewables, Global Status Report 2006 |year= 2006 |accessdate= 3 April 2007 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110718181410/http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/download/RE_GSR_2006_Update.pdf |archivedate= 18 July 2011 |df= dmy-all }}{{cite journal |first1= Ingvar B. |last1= Fridleifsson, |first2= Ruggero |last2= Bertani |first3= Ernst |last3= Huenges |first4= John W. |last4= Lund |first5= Arni |last5= Ragnarsson |first6= Ladislaus |last6= Rybach |date= 11 February 2008 |title= The possible role and contribution of geothermal energy to the mitigation of climate change |conference= IPCC Scoping Meeting on Renewable Energy Sources |editor= O. Hohmeyer and T. Trittin |location= Luebeck, Germany |pages= 59–80 |url= http://iga.igg.cnr.it/documenti/IGA/Fridleifsson_et_al_IPCC_Geothermal_paper_2008.pdf |format= pdf |accessdate= 6 April 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110722030340/http://iga.igg.cnr.it/documenti/IGA/Fridleifsson_et_al_IPCC_Geothermal_paper_2008.pdf |archivedate= 22 July 2011 |df= dmy-all }} Heat pumps are small and widely distributed, so estimates of their total capacity are uncertain and range up to {{val|100|u=GW}}. ==== Bio energy ==== {{Main article|Biomass|Biogas|Biofuel}} Until the beginning of the nineteenth century biomass was the predominant fuel, today it has only a small share of the overall energy supply. Electricity produced from [[biomass]] sources was estimated at 44 GW for 2005. Biomass electricity generation increased by over 100% in Germany, Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland, and Spain. A further 220 GW was used for heating (in 2004), bringing the total energy consumed from biomass to around 264 GW. The use of biomass fires for cooking is excluded. World production of [[Ethanol fuel|bioethanol]] increased by 8% in 2005 to reach {{convert|33|GL|usgal|lk=on}}, with most of the increase in the United States, bringing it level to the levels of consumption in Brazil. [[Biodiesel]] increased by 85% to {{convert|3.9|GL|usgal}}, making it the fastest growing renewable energy source in 2005. Over 50% is produced in Germany. == By country == {{Main article|List of renewable energy topics by country}} {{See also|:category:Energy by country|l1=Energy by country|Worldwide energy supply|List of countries by energy consumption per capita}} {{Pie chart | thumb =right | caption =World total final consumption of 13,699 [[Tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]] by region in 2014 (IEA, 2016) | other = | label1 =[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] | value1 =38.4 | color1 =#66CCFF | label2 =Middle East | value2 =5.3 | color2 =#FFFF57 | label3 =Non-OECD Eurasia | value3 =8.2 | color3 =#009a39 | label4 =China | value4 =22.4 | color4 =#de2821 | label5 = Rest of Asia | value5 =12.7 | color5 =pink | label6 =Non-OECD Americas | value6 =4.7 | color6 =#211873 | label7 =Africa | value7 =5.6 | color7 =#ef8e39 | label8 =Bunkers | value8 =2.7 | color8 =#313c42 }} [[File:Global energy consumption.jpg|thumb|right|World energy consumption per capita, 1950-2004]] Energy consumption is loosely correlated with [[Gross National Product#Gross National Product|gross national product]] and climate, but there is a large difference even between the most highly developed countries, such as Japan and Germany with an energy consumption rate of 6 kW per person and the [[Energy use in the United States|United States]] with an energy consumption rate of 11.4 kW per person. In developing countries, particularly those that are sub-tropical or tropical such as India, the per person energy use rate is closer to 0.7 kW. Bangladesh has the lowest consumption rate with 0.2 kW per person. The US consumes 25% of the world's energy with a share of global GDP at 22% and a share of the world population at 4.59%.{{cite web |url= http://esa.un.org/UNPP/ |title= World Population Prospects |publisher= United Nations |accessdate= 7 February 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070321013235/http://esa.un.org/unpp/ |archive-date= 21 March 2007 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }} The most significant growth of energy consumption is currently taking place in China, which has been growing at 5.5% per year over the last 25 years. Its population of 1.3 billion people (19.6% of the world population) is consuming energy at a rate of 1.6 kW per person. One measurement of efficiency is [[energy intensity]]. This is a measure of the amount of energy it takes a country to produce a dollar of gross domestic product. {{multiple image |direction = horizontal |align= center |width1= 255 |width2= 250 |image1=Energy Use per Capita.png |image2=GDP per unit of energy use.png |caption1=The World Bank: Kilograms of oil equivalent (2011) |caption2=The World Bank: PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent (2011) }} {{clear left}} === Oil === {{Main article|Petroleum}} Saudi Arabia, Russia and the United States accounted for 34% of oil production in 2011. Thus the total energy consumption was around 160 PWh (ca {{val|550e15|ul=Btu}}). The efficiency of a typical existing power plant is around 38%.{{cite web |title= Energy efficiency measures and technological improvements. |url= http://www.e8.org/index.jsp?numPage=138 |publisher= e8.org |accessdate= 21 January 2007 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070204112155/http://www.e8.org/index.jsp?numPage=138 |archivedate= 4 February 2007 |df= dmy-all }} Article by group of ten leading electricity companies The new generation of gas-fired plants reaches a substantially higher efficiency of 55%. Coal is the most common fuel for the world's electricity plants.{{cite web |url= http://www.worldcoal.org/assets_cm/files/PDF/coal_fact_card_2006.pdf |archive-url= http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160517000455/http://www.worldcoal.org/assets_cm/files/PDF/coal_fact_card_2006.pdf |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 2016-05-17 |title= Coal Facts 2006 Edition |publisher= [[World Coal Institute]] |format= PDF |date= September 2006 |accessdate= 8 April 2007 }} Another report gives different values for the sectors, apparently due to different definitions. According to this, total world energy use per sector in 2008 was industry 28%, transport 27% and residential and service 36%. Division was about the same in the year 2000. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders floatright" style="text-align:right;" |+ World energy use per sectorTable 56, Total world energy use per sector 1990–2008 (pp. 48-49), in {{cite web|title=Energy in Sweden — facts and figures 2010|url=https://webbshop.cm.se/System/DownloadResource.ashx?p=Energimyndigheten&rl=default:/Resources/Permanent/Static/e0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f/ET2010_46.pdf|publisher=Swedish Energy Agency|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014221749/http://webbshop.cm.se/System/DownloadResource.ashx?p=Energimyndigheten&rl=default%3A%2FResources%2FPermanent%2FStatic%2Fe0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f%2FET2010_46.pdf|archivedate=14 October 2013|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} (see also [https://energimyndigheten.a-w2m.se/FolderContents.mvc/Download?ResourceId=2609 Energy in Sweden 2011]), data from [[International Energy Agency|IEA]] [https://www.iea.org/statistics/relateddatabases/energybalancesofnon-oecdcountries/ Energy Balances of Non-OECD countries] 2010. |- ! scope="row" | Year ! scope="col" | 2000 ! scope="col" | 2008 ! scope="col" | 2000 ! scope="col" | 2008 |- ! scope="col" | Sector ! scope="col" colspan=2 | TWh ! scope="col" colspan=2 | %* |- ! scope="row" | Industry | 21,733 || 27,273 || 26.5 || 27.8 |- ! scope="row" | Transport | 22,563 || 26,742 || 27.5 || 27.3 |- ! scope="row" | Residential and service | 30,555 || 35,319 || 37.3 || 36.0 |- ! scope="row" | Non-energy use | 7,119 || 8,688 || 8.7 || 8.9 |- style="font-weight:bold;" ! scope="row" style="font-weight:bold;" | Total* | 81,970 || 98,022 || 100 || 100 |- style="text-align:left;font-size:smaller;" | colspan=5 | Source: IEA 2010, Total is calculated from the given sectors

Total world energy supply (2008) 143,851 TWh |} ===European Union=== The [[European Environmental Agency]] (EEA) measures final energy consumption (does not include energy used in production and lost in transportation) and finds that the transport sector is responsible for 31.8% of final energy consumption, households 26.2%, industry 25.6%, [[service (economics)|services]] 13.5% and agriculture 2.9% in 2012.European Environmental Agency. {{Cite web|url = http://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/indicators/final-energy-consumption-by-sector-8/assessment-2|title = Final energy consumption by sector and fuel (CSI 027/ENER 016) - Assessment published Jan 2015|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} Retrieved 21 June 2015. The use of energy is responsible for the majority of greenhouse gas emissions (79%), with the energy sector representing 31%, transport 19%, industry 13%, households 9% and others 7%.Eva Hoos [[European Commission]] 2011. [http://eme2.eu/cust/documentrequest.aspx?DocID=148 A new Directive on Energy Efficiency]. Retrieved 11 October 2011. While [[efficient energy use]] and resource efficiency are growing as public policy issues, more than 70% of [[coal plants]] in the [[European Union]] are more than 20 years old and operate at an efficiency level of between 32–40%.[[European Commission]] 2011. [http://eme2.eu/cust/documentrequest.aspx?DocID=152 Impact Assessment Accompanying the document Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on energy efficiency and amending and subsequently repealing Directives 2004/8/EC and 2006/32/EC]. p. 106. Retrieved 11 October 2011. Technological developments in the 1990s have allowed efficiencies in the range of 40–45% at newer plants. However, according to an impact assessment by the [[European Commission]], this is still below the [[Best available technology|best available technological]] (BAT) efficiency levels of 46–49%. With [[gas-fired power plant]]s the average efficiency is 52% compared to 58–59% with best available technology (BAT), and gas and oil [[Boiler (steam generator)|boiler plants]] operate at average 36% efficiency (BAT delivers 47%). According to that same impact assessment by the [[European Commission]], raising the efficiency of all new plants and the majority of existing plants, through the setting of authorisation and permit conditions, to an average generation efficiency of 51.5% in 2020 would lead to a reduction in annual consumption of {{convert|15|km3|abbr=on}} of natural gas and {{convert|25|Mt|abbr=on}} of coal. {{coord|53|05|49|N|6|35|06|E|region:NL-DR_type:landmark|notes=<ref>{{cite book | last = van der Sanden| first = Wijnand | authorlink = Wijnand van der Sanden | title = Mens en moeras: veenlijken in Nederland van de bronstijd tot en met de Romeinse tijd | publisher = Drents Museum | location = Assen | year = 1990 | pages = 61 Fig 12 | isbn = 90-70884-31-3 }}</ref>|display=title}} [[File:Meisje van Yde, Drents Museum, N1897 VI1.jpg|thumb|Head and trunk of Yde Girl]] [[Image:Yde_bog_girl.jpg|thumb|Location where the Yde Girl was found]]
'''Yde Girl''' ({{IPAc-en|lang|ˈ|ɪ|d|ə|audio=Yde IPA.ogg}}) is a [[bog body]] found in the ''Stijfveen'' [[peat]] bog near the village of [[Yde]], [[Netherlands]]. She was found on 12 May 1897 and was reputedly uncannily well-preserved when discovered (especially her [[hair]]), but by the time the body was turned over to the authorities a [[fortnight]] later it had been severely damaged and deteriorated.<ref name=deem>{{cite web|last=Deem|first=James M.|url=http://www.mummytombs.com/museums/nl.assen.drents.yde.htm|title=Drents Museum in Assen, the Netherlands: The Yde Girl|accessdate=16 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517152742/http://www.mummytombs.com/museums/nl.assen.drents.yde.htm|archivedate=17 May 2014|df=}}</ref> Most of her teeth had been pulled from the skull by villagers as well as a large amount of hair.<ref name=visit/> The peat cutting tools had also been reported to have severely damaged the body.<ref name=deem/>
==Examination== [[Image:DrentseBody.jpg|thumb|left|The Yde Girl's body]]
[[Carbon-14]] tests have indicated that Yde Girl died between 54 [[Common Era|BCE]] and 128 CE at an approximate age of 16 years.<ref name=deem/> She had long reddish blond hair, but one side of her head was initially thought to have been shaved before she died. Recent studies of [[Windeby I]], however, have suggested that the shaved hair phenomenon in some bog bodies may simply attest to one side of the head being exposed to oxygen slightly longer than the other. Scans have shown that she suffered from [[scoliosis]]. She stood at {{convert|137|cm|ftin}}, which is comparatively small for a sixteen-year-old.<ref name=deem/>
The body was found clad in a woolen cape and with a woolen band, made in a braiding technique known as [[sprang]], wrapped around the neck, suggesting she was executed or sacrificed.<ref name=city>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-110791280.html|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=Pittsburgh City Paper|title=BEST MUSEUM EXHIBIT: THE MYSTERIOUS BOG PEOPLE|date=7 December 2005}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref name=dan>{{cite news|last=Nephin|first=Dan|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-110791280.html|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=AP Online|title=Mummy Exhibit Shows Off Interactive Side|date=6 July 2005}}{{subscription required}}</ref> There was also a stab wound in the area of her collarbone, but that was not determined as the cause of death. It is thought that she may have died while unconscious, as defensive wounds were absent on the hand that was recovered from the body, unlike a similar case in Germany, the [[Kayhausen Boy]], who had a cut on his left hand from an apparent defense attempt.<ref name=deem/> As with most bog bodies, the skin and features are still preserved because of the [[tannic acid]] in the marsh water. When Yde Girl was excavated, the diggers accidentally caused a wound to the skull. Only the torso of the girl, the head, the right hand and the feet remain intact today. The rest of her body was not preserved or had been damaged by peat cutting tools.
==Exhibit== [[Image:Yde Face Reconstruction.jpg|thumb|1992 facial reconstruction by artist [[Richard Neave]]]]
The Yde Girl was put on display and further study was not carried out on the remains until 1992. [[Richard Neave]], of University of Manchester, took a [[CT scan]] of the skull of Yde Girl and determined her age, both anatomically and historically.<ref name=visit/><ref name=city/><ref>{{cite news|last=Mohd Isa|first=Marisa|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-82747279.html|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=News Straits Times|title=Unveiling mummy secrets|date=6 January 2006}}{{subscription required}}</ref> The Yde Girl became internationally known when Neave made a reconstruction of her head, using techniques from [[plastic surgery]] and criminal [[pathology]].<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Prag | first1 = John | last2 = Neave | first2 = Richard | title = Making faces: using forensic and archaeological evidence |trans-title=Bodies from the Bog | year = 1997 | publisher = British Museum | location = London | language = | isbn = 0-7141-1743-9 | pages = 157–171 }}</ref> Due to the state of the body, the work on the reconstruction included some guesswork, for example, the nose.<ref name=deem/> Yde Girl and her modern reconstruction are displayed at the [[Drents Museum]] in [[Assen]].
Yde Girl, along with [[Roter Franz]] and the [[Weerdinge Men]], were transported across the world for a museum tour in both the early and mid 2000s.<ref name=visit>{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=Sue Ellen|title=Visit the mummies before they leave for L.A.|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-71012131.html|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=Sunday Gazette-Mail|date=14 August 2005}}</ref><ref name=city/><ref name=dan/> Due to the intensity of the girl's death, protests in [[Canada]] prevented the tour from traveling through several locations in the country.<ref>{{cite news|title=CULTURE-CANADA: 'BOG PEOPLE' MUMMIES PROVOKE PROTESTS|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=Inter Press Service English News Wire|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2003/01/arts-weekly-culture-canada-bog-people-display-provokes-protest/|first=Mark|last=Bourrie|date=13 January 2003}}</ref>
